sen.j: 大内裏（だいだいり）とは、平安京における宮城を指す。
sen.e: Daidairi means an imperial Palace in the ancient capital of Heian.
Daidairi is an imperial Palace in the ancient capital of Heian.
Daidairi is an Imperial Palace in the ancient capital of Heian.

sen.j: 12世紀以降、宮城内の天皇在所である内裏を「大内裏」と表記することがあったが、14世紀になると宮城全体を「大内裏」と称するようになり、この用例が一般化した。
sen.e: After twelfth century, it often meant the particular Palace where emperor stay within the Imperial Palace as 'Daidairi', but after fourteenth century, the whole Imperial Palace was called 'Daidairi' and the usage of this expression became common.

After the twelfth century, it often meant a particular Palace where emperor stays within the Imperial Palace as 'Daidairi," but after the fourteenth century, the whole Imperial Palace was called 'Daidairi' and the usage of this expression became common.

After the 12th century, it often meant a particular Palace where emperor stays within the Imperial Palace as 'Daidairi,' but after the 14th century, the whole Imperial Palace was called 'Daidairi' and the usage of this expression became common.

sen.j: 平安京の北辺中央に位置する。
sen.e: The Daidairi locates in the centre of the north end of the ancient capital of Heian.
The Daidairi is located in the centre of the north end of the ancient capital of Heian.
The Daidairi is located in the center of the north end of the ancient capital of Heian.

sen.j: 政変や失火のためたびたび焼失し、平安中期頃から再建されていない。
sen.e: The Palace was burnt down due to the political incident or there were some accidental fires, it has not been rebuilt since middle of the Heian period.
The Palace was burnt down either due to a political incident or there some accidental fire, it has not been rebuilt since middle of the Heian period.
The Palace was burnt down either due to a political incident or there some accidental fire, it has not been rebuilt since middle of the Heian period.

sen.j: 東西約1.2km、南北約1.4kmの、行政施設・国家儀式や年中行事を行う殿舎、天皇の居住する内裏が設置されている区域であった。
sen.e: This was an area of about 1.2 kilometer long in east west, and 1.4 kilometer long in South North, and it had the facility with the palace to have an administration institute and national ceremony, yearly event, it also had a Palace where emperor lived in.

This was an area about 1.2 kilometers long running east to west, and 1.4 kilometer long in North to South, and it was provided with an administration institute and a national ceremony, facilitated yearly events, and it also had a Palace where the emperor lived.

This was an area about 1.2 kilometers long running east to west, and 1.4 kilometer long in North to South, and it was provided with an administration institute and a national ceremony, facilitated yearly events, and it also had a Palace where the emperor lived.

sen.j: 官僚やその家族の邸宅も大内裏の内部にあり、それらの殿舎は内裏の清涼殿に廊下でつながっていた。
sen.e: There were villas for the government officials and their families inside the Daidairi, and those villas were connected with the corridor to the Seiryoden (name of one of the Imperial Palace in Heian period) inside the palace.

There were villas for the government officials and their families inside the Daidairi, and those villas were connected with a corridor to the Seiryoden (name of one of the Imperial Palaces during the Heian period) inside the palace.

There were villas for the government officials and their families inside the Daidairi, and those villas were connected with a corridor to the Seiryoden (name of one of the Imperial Palaces during the Heian period) inside the palace.

sen.j: 大内裏の周囲は築地塀の大垣が張り巡らされており、この築地を「宮城垣」または「外の重（とのえ）」という。
sen.e: There was a large fence made by a roofed mud-wall around the Daidairi, which the outside fence was called 'Miya-mon Gate' or 'Tonoe'.
There was a large fence made as a roofed mud-wall around the Daidairi, of which the outside fence was called 'Miya-mon Gate' or 'Tonoe.'
There was a large fence made as a roofed mud-wall around the Daidairi, of which the outside fence was called 'Miya-mon Gate' or 'Tonoe.'

sen.j: 門は最も外側に宮城門（みやぎもん）が位置し、内裏外郭の門を宮門（みやもん）、内郭の門を閤門（こうもん）という。
sen.e: The Miyagi-mon Gate was the far outside gate, and the gate just outside the gate was called Miya-mon gate, the inside fence was called Ko-mon Gate.
The Miyagi-mon Gate was the furthest outside gate, just and was called the Miya-mon gate, the gate for the inside fence was called the Ko-mon Gate.
The Miyagi-mon Gate was the furthest outside gate, just outside was called the Miya-mon gate, the gate for the inside fence was called the Ko-mon Gate.

sen.j: 大内裏の宮城門は
sen.e: The name of the Miyagi-mon Gate inside the Daidairi
The name of the Miyagi-mon Gate inside the Daidairi
The name of the Miyagi-mon Gate inside the Daidairi

sen.j: 南面に朱雀門、皇嘉門、美福門
sen.e: Suzaku-mon Gate, Koka-mon Gate, Bufuku-mon Gate on the south side
Suzaku-mon Gate, Koka-mon Gate, Bufuku-mon Gate on the south side
Suzaku-mon Gate, Koka-mon Gate, Bifuku-mon Gate on the south side

sen.j: 北面に安嘉門、偉鑒門、達智門
sen.e: Anka-mon Gate, Ikan-mon Gate, Tacchi-mon Gate on the north side
Anka-mon Gate, Ikan-mon Gate, Tacchi-mon Gate on the north side
Anka-mon Gate, Ikan-mon Gate, Tacchi-mon Gate on the north side

sen.j: 東面に上東門、陽明門、待賢門、郁芳門
sen.e: Joto-mon Gate, Yomei-mon Gate, Taiken-mon Gate, Ikuho-mon Gate on the east side
Joto-mon Gate, Yomei-mon Gate, Taiken-mon Gate, Ikuho-mon Gate on the east side
Joto-mon Gate, Yomei-mon Gate, Taiken-mon Gate, Ikuho-mon Gate on the east side

sen.j: 西面に上西門、殷富門、藻壁門、談天門
sen.e: Josai-mon Gate, Inpu-mon Gate, Soheki-mon Gate, Danten-mon Gate on the west side
Josai-mon Gate, Inpu-mon Gate, Soheki-mon Gate, Danten-mon Gate on the west side
Josai-mon Gate, Inpu-mon Gate, Soheki-mon Gate, Danten-mon Gate on the west side

sen.j: が構えられていた（画像Heiankyo map.png参考）。
sen.e: The above gates were established. (Please refer to the images of Heiankyo map.png.)
The above gates were established. (Please refer to the images of Heiankyo mappng.)
The above gates were established. (Please refer to the images of Heiankyo map.png.)

sen.j: このうち上東門と上西門は大蔵通用門として「屋根を設けず築地を開いただけ」の門であったため、「土の門」＝「土御門」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Out of above gates, Joto-mon Gate and Josai-mon Gate were called 'Tsuchi no mon' (the gate made out of mud), 'Tsuchimikado', since they had a tile-roofed mud wall without having proper roof to use as service entrance for Okura. (the Ministry of finance)
sen.cmt: 大蔵通用門→Okura service entrance[定訳不明]
sen.e: Out of above gates, Joto-mon Gate and Josai-mon Gate were called 'Tsuchi no mon' (the gate made out of mud), 'Tsuchimikado', since they had a tile-roofed mud wall without having proper roof to use as service entrance for Okura. (the Ministry of finance)

Out of above gates, Joto-mon Gate and Josai-mon Gate were called 'Tsuchi no mon' (the gate made out of mud), 'Tsuchimikado,' since they had a tile-roofed mud wall without having proper roof to use as service entrance for Okura. (the Ministry of finance)

sen.j: この門を出た通りが「土御門大路」であり、姓氏の土御門家や藤原氏邸宅土御門殿はこの地名に由来している。
sen.e: The name of the street just outside of this gate is 'Tsuchimikado Avenue', which the surname of the Tsuchimikado family and Fujiwara family's mansion, Tsuchimikado dono (mansion) belong to this name of the place.

The name of the street just outside of this gate is 'Tsuchimikado Avenue', which the surname of the Tsuchimikado family and Fujiwara family's mansion, Tsuchimikado dono (mansion) belong to this name of the place.

The name of the street just outside of this gate is 'Tsuchimikado Avenue,' which the surname of the Tsuchimikado family and Fujiwara family's mansion, Tsuchimikado dono (mansion) belong to this name of the place.

sen.j: 上東門と上西門を除く12門は「宮城十二門」と総称される。
sen.e: The twelve gates excluding Joto-mon Gate and Josai-mon Gate were called 'The Twelve Gates for the Imperial Palace.
sen.cmt: 宮城十二門→the Twelve Gates for the Imperial Palace[定訳不明]
sen.e: The twelve gates excluding Joto-mon Gate and Josai-mon Gate, were called 'The Twelve Gates of the Imperial Palace.'
The twelve gates excluding Joto-mon Gate and Josai-mon Gate, were called 'The Twelve Gates of the Imperial Palace.'

sen.j: なお、幕末まで天皇が住んだ京都御所は、1331年に光厳天皇が里内裏だった土御門東洞院殿を皇居として定めたものである。
sen.e: By the way the Kyoto Imperial Palace where the Emperor lived until the last days of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), was established as the Imperial Palace by Emperor Kogon, where the Emperor used to use Tsuchimikado Higashi Toin Palace as his Satodairi (temporally palace).

By the way the Kyoto Imperial Palace where the Emperor lived until the last days of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), was established as the Imperial Palace by Emperor Kogon, where the Emperor used to use Tsuchimikado Higashi Toin Palace as his Satodairi (temporally palace).

By the way the Kyoto Imperial Palace where the Emperor lived until the last days of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), was established as the Imperial Palace by Emperor Kogon in 1331, where the Emperor used to use Tsuchimikado Higashi Toin Palace as his Satodairi (temporally palace).

sen.j: 1855年に松平定信（寛政の改革で有名な老中とは別人）を総奉行として律令制の形式に則って改築された。
sen.e: In 1855 this palace was built under Ritsuryo Style (a system of centralized government based on ritsuryo codes) having Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA (he was not the same famous person as a Senior Councilor in the Kansei Reforms) as Sobugyo. (Grand Magistrate)

In 1855 this palace was built under Ritsuryo Style (a system of centralized government based on ritsuryo codes) having Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA (he was not the same famous person as a Senior Councilor in the Kansei Reforms) as Sobugyo. (Grand Magistrate)

In 1855 this palace was built under Ritsuryo Style (a system of centralized government based on ritsuryo codes) having Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA (he was not the same famous person as a Senior Councilor in the Kansei Reforms) as Sobugyo (Grand Magistrate).

sen.j: 1895年（明治28年）には平安神宮が建立され、内部に大極殿、応天門など大内裏朝堂院の施設が縮尺復元された。
sen.e: In 1895 the Heian-Jingu Shrine was built, there were restoration of the facilities like Daigoku-den building, Oten-mon Gate and Daidairi Chodoin (a large main hall of Daidairi) in small scale than original ones inside the Palace.

In 1895 the Heian-Jingu Shrine was built, restoration was done on the facilities like; Daigoku-den building, Oten-mon Gate and Daidairi Chodoin (a large main hall of Daidairi) in small scale than original ones inside the Palace.

In 1895 the Heian-Jingu Shrine was built, restoration was done on the facilities like; Daigoku-den building, Oten-mon Gate and Daidairi Chodoin (a large main hall of Daidairi) in small scale than original ones inside the Palace.

sen.j: 豊楽院：朝堂院の西にあり、節会の宴や外国使節歓待などが行われた。
sen.e: Burakuin : located west of Chodoin and it was used to hold the Sechie event (official events of the Imperial Palace) or to welcome delegates from overseas.
Burakuin: located west of Chodoin, it was used to hold the Sechie event (official events of the Imperial Palace) or to welcome delegates from overseas.

sen.j: 紫宸殿：内裏の正殿。
sen.e: Shishin-den Hall : the main hall of the Imperial Palace
Shishin-den Hall: the main hall of the Imperial Palace

sen.j: 平安中期以降は大極殿に変わり、儀式、公務、謁見の間として使われた。
sen.e: It was changed to Daigokuden building and was used as the place to hold the ceremony, government affairs or the place for Emperor to see people.
It was changed to the Daigokuden building and was used as a place to hold ceremonies, government affairs, or as a place for the Emperor to see people.
It was changed to the Daigokuden building after the mid Heian period and was used as a place to hold ceremonies, government affairs, or as a place for the Emperor to see people.

Koryo-den (one of the palaces within the Imperial Palace where Nyogo live)

sen.j: 仁寿殿：相撲観戦、元服の儀式など天皇の私的な行事に使われる。
sen.e: Jiju-den (Ninju-den) : The Palace is used for watching Sumo games or emperor's private function like coming-of-age ceremony.
Jiju-den (Ninju-den): This Palace is used for watching Sumo games or for the emperor's private functions like the coming-of-age ceremony.

sen.j: 宴の松原：内裏の西に位置する空閑地で、もとは内裏の建て替え用地だったと言われる。
sen.e: En no Matsubara : unused land which locate west of the Palace and it was originally the land to rebuilt the Imperial Palace.

sen.j: 八省庁：中務省、式部省、治部省、民部省、兵部省、刑部省、大蔵省、宮内省の各省。
sen.e: Nakatsukasa-sho Ministry (the official position to serve emperor closely and helped issuing emperor's order and etc), Shikibu-sho Ministry,(the official position in charge of personnel) Jibu-sho Ministry,(the official position in charge of surname, succession of the family or marriage, funerals of government officials) Minbu-sho Ministry, (the official position in charge of family registration, looking after mountains and rivers, taxes and etc.,) Hyobu-sho Ministry, (the official position in charge of military) Gyobu-sho Ministry, (the official position in charge of crimes and court) Okura-sho Ministry, (the official position in charge of finances) Kunai-sho Ministry. (the official posion in charge of dealing matters of Imperial family)
sen.cmt: 中務省、式部省、治部省、民部省、兵部省、刑部省、大蔵省、宮内省→[定訳不明]
sen.e: 八省庁: Nakatsukasa-sho Ministry (the official position to closely serve the emperor and assist issuing the emperor's orders and etc), Shikibu-sho Ministry, (the official position in charge of personnel) Jibu-sho Ministry,(the official position in charge of surname, succession of the family or marriage, funerals of government officials) Minbu-sho Ministry, (the official position in charge of family registration, looking after mountains and rivers, taxes and etc.,) Hyobu-sho Ministry, (the official position in charge of the military) Gyobu-sho Ministry, (the official position in charge of crimes and court) Okura-sho Ministry, (the official position in charge of finances) Kunai-sho Ministry. (the official position in charge of dealing with matters of the Imperial family)

Eight Ministries: Nakatsukasa-sho Ministry (the official position to closely serve the emperor and assist issuing the emperor's orders, etc.), Shikibu-sho Ministry, (the official position in charge of personnel), Jibu-sho Ministry, (the official position in charge of surname, succession of the family or marriage, funerals of government officials), Minbu-sho Ministry (the official position in charge of family registration, looking after mountains and rivers, taxes, etc.), Hyobu-sho Ministry (the official position in charge of the military), Gyobu-sho Ministry (the official position in charge of crimes and court), Okura-sho Ministry (the official position in charge of finances), Kunai-sho Ministry (the official position in charge of dealing with matters of the Imperial family)
sen.cmt: 八省庁→Eight Ministriesコンマ位置移動スペース挿入"and etc"→", etc."に変更しました。
